Snowfire, as I noted at the beginning of the test, sending in results after=
 I already announced what the object is can't of course be part of the expe=
riment.=C2=A0 Someone could simply read what I said, and it could then infl=
uence their own interpretation of ramdom noise, for example, or they could =
say "I got it but forgot to mail it", or a host of other reasons.

To make =
the experiment as objective as possible, only answers sent during the exper=
iment's timeframe can be valid.

SnowfireL@...> wrote:

ect: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment 20100710 - RESULTS! [1 Attachment]

om included below]
        
      
      


Haha, David did get it right RJ=
, I just didn't send this one in.=C2=A0 He 
says, Radio twice!!!=C2=A0 So, =
cool, I didn't think he was right, but i guess, 
he was after all. sf
=C2=

erer@yahoo. com writes:

Snowfire, I do h=
ave more than one monitor.=C2=A0 
        Some are in my closet (so not in =
this room, and not near me).=C2=A0 And 
        the others in this room are=
 laptops.=C2=A0 None of the laptops had 
        anything on them.=C2=A0 An=
d the monitors in the closet just have other 
        equipment on them.

B=
ut now that I've sent out a picture of the 
        monitor, next time ever=
yone knows what it looks like, so maybe that will 
        help.=C2=A0 Or, =
I'm open to suggestions for other locations for the 
        object in ques=
tion too.=C2=A0 This was just close to me (I would see it 
        every da=
y), and was also the monitor I use for this 
        newsgroup.

          Well, RJ don't know why they cou=
ldn't get it, maybe that thing doesn't look like a monitor to them, 
      =
    looks more like a box, do you have more then one monitor in your 
     =
     house?=C2=A0 If David got it wrong, it was my fault for not 
         =
 understanding Him.=C2=A0 sf
          =C2=A0
          
          In a mes=
sage dated 7/14/2010 2:20:10 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time, 
          rastere=
r@yahoo. com writes:
          =C2=A0 
            
            
Thanks aga=
in for everyone who participated! I admire your 
            courage and mo=
tivation to try different methods, see what works, and 
            try to =
improve everyone's understanding of EVP-ITC.

If you 
            recall, o=
n 7/10/2010 I placed an object on top of my computer 
            monitor, =
right in front of me, and left it there until today, 
            7/14/2010=
, noon Denver time. The experiment was for participants to 
            det=
ermine what it was. Vague or partial answers wouldn't be counted 
         =
   (for example, just colors, shapes, sizes, what it's made of, etc): 
    =
        we're looking for what it is. Participants could use their ghost 
 =
           boxes, EVP recorders, or I suppose any other means they 
       =
     chose.

In order to keep me honest, I took a picture of the 
         =
   object at the start of the experiment and loaded it to the Files 
      =
      section (RJ folder) of this group. If you can follow the link, it is =

            here:

http://tech. groups.yahoo. com/group/ 
            EVP-=
ITC/files/ RJ/RJ.20100710. 1.zip

The idea was that 
            you could =
download the file at the beginning of the test, and 'keep 
            it s=
afe' on your computer. Then at the end of the test, I would 
            re=
lease the password so you could reveal the contents of the file. 
         =
   That way, you were in control of the original image during the 
        =
    entire test, not me. 

The password for that file is: 
            123B=
lastOff
Instructions, if you need them, are also in that RJ 
            fo=
lder.

And if you did not care to download the zip file 
            before=
 the test, I will post the final image there too.

So to 
            the r=
esults:

Number of participants: 5
Total tries: 
            8
Ambiguous an=
swers: 0
Correct answers: 0

Object: A 
            radio
Uzipped picture:
=
http://tech. groups.yahoo. com/group/ 
            EVP-ITC/files/ RJ/RJ.201=
00710. 1.JPG

So what do the 
            results mean? All that we can rea=
lly agree on from this experiment 
            is that no participant, with=
 whatever theories or methods or 
            technology they used, was abl=
e to correctly determine the object. We 
            can't say those theori=
es or methods or technologies never work. Just 
            as we can't say=
 they do. Just that, for whatever reason, they did 
            not work th=
is time. Readers can take the results, use them to 
            improve or =
change their methods, or keep doing what they're 
            doing.

If an=
yone has any observations, comments, or ideas for 
            improvement,=
 let me know. I hope to get a new experiment up and 
            running so=
on. Since there wasn't much participation Mon-Wed, I think 
            the=
 next experiment will be arranged to mostly span the 
            weekends.=


Again, thanks to everyone who participated in this 
            first exp=
eriment.
